message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and findings suggest cholecystitis, and the HIDA scan demonstrates non-filling of the gallbladder, which is seen in acute cholecystitis. Entrapped epithelial crypts are a histopathological feature of chronic cholecystitis. None of the other options are associated with cholecystitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, blood work, and imaging findings suggest chronic cholecystitis with cholelithiasis, in which there can be entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder. The other options do not match the histopathological features seen in chronic cholecystitis. Neutrophilic infiltration, vascular congestion, and fibrin deposition are seen in acute cholecystitis. Lymphoid aggregates are seen in chronic cholecystitis as well, but they are not the most notable feature. Hyalinized collagen and dystrophic calcification are seen in chronic pancreatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and test results suggest chronic cholecystitis, which is often associated with microscopic examination of the gallbladder wall showing entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder. Option A describes acute cholecystitis, Option B is not associated with chronic cholecystitis, and Option D is associated with chronic inflammation elsewhere but not specifically in the gallbladder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and imaging findings suggest chronic cholecystitis. Entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder is a histopathological feature in chronic cholecystitis. The other options are not commonly present in chronic cholecystitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings are consistent with chronic cholecystitis, which is characterized by thickening of the gallbladder wall and gallstones. Option C describes the histopathological feature of entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder, a common finding in chronic cholecystitis. The other options describe features seen in other conditions such as acute cholecystitis and chronic pancreatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, lab results, and imaging findings are consistent with cholecystitis, and the HIDA scan confirmed non-filling of the gallbladder. Entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder are a histopathological feature of chronic cholecystitis. Neutrophilic infiltration, vascular congestion, and fibrin deposition are seen in acute cholecystitis. Minimal lymphoid aggregates are nonspecific findings. Hyalinized collagen and dystrophic calcification can occur in chronic inflammation but are not specific to cholecystitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation and imaging findings suggest chronic cholecystitis with a non-functioning gallbladder. Entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder is a histopathological feature commonly seen in chronic cholecystitis. Neutrophilic infiltration with vascular congestion and fibrin deposition in the gallbladder is seen in acute cholecystitis. Minimal lymphoid aggregates are seen in chronic hepatitis. Hyalinized collagen and dystrophic calcification in the submucosal layer are seen in some cases of chronic pancreatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The thickened gallbladder wall and non-filling of the gallbladder in the HIDA scan suggest chronic cholecystitis with impaired gallbladder function. The entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder is a histopathological feature commonly seen in chronic cholecystitis. Options A, B, and D are not associated with chronic cholecystitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of cholecystitis and imaging shows non-filling of the gallbladder, indicating chronic cholecystitis. The histopathological feature of entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder is a characteristic finding of chronic cholecystitis. Option (A) describes acute cholecystitis, option (B) is not specific to any gallbladder pathology, and option (D) describes a different condition called porcelain gallbladder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and blood work suggest cholecystitis, and the thickened gallbladder with gallstones seen on ultrasound confirms this diagnosis. The HIDA scan results suggest cystic duct obstruction. Among the options provided, only option (C) describes a histopathological feature seen in chronic cholecystitis, which is the presence of entrapped epithelial crypts seen as pockets of epithelium in the wall of the gallbladder.
